raw_text:
Legendary Dutch boss Michels dies
 
 Legendary Dutch coach Rinus Michels, the man credited with developing "total football", has died aged 77.
 
 Referred to in the Netherlands as "the General", Michels led the Dutch at the 1974 World Cup - when they reached the final only to lose 2-1 to Germany. However, he guided his side to the 1988 European Championship title with a 2-0 win over the Soviet Union in the final. Michels played for Ajax and coached the side to four national titles between 1965-71 and a European Cup in 1971. His 1970s Dutch team was built around Johan Cruyff and Johan Neeskens and introduced the concept of 'total football' to the world. The strategy was to foster team coherence and individual imagination - with all players possessing the skills to play in any part of the pitch. Cruyff was the on-field organiser of a team whose players rotated in and out of defence at will and was encouraged to play creative attacking football. Michels had recently undergone heart surgery and Dutch football federation (KNVB) spokesman Frank Huizinga said: "He was one of the best coaches we had in history." The no-nonsense coach also enjoyed spells at Barcelona, who he took to a Spanish title in 1974, FC Cologne and Bayer Leverkusen. Michels, named coach of the century by world football's governing body Fifa in 1999, also won five caps for the Netherlands as a bruising centre forward. Dutch sports minister Clemence Ross-van Dorp said: "He was the man who, together with Cruyff, made Dutch football big."
llama3.2:1b: Legendary coach Rinus Michels dies at 77 after heart surgery and had a storied career in the Netherlands, leading the country to European Championship titles.
He developed "total football" which emphasized individual imagination and team coherence, and his teams played attractive attacking football with players who could play anywhere on the pitch.
llama3.2:3b: Rinus Michels, a legendary Dutch coach credited with developing "total football", has died at 77 after undergoing heart surgery.
He led the Netherlands to the 1974 World Cup final and won the European Championship title in 1988.
Michels coached Ajax to four national titles, including a European Cup win, and played for Ajax as a forward.
gemma2:2b: Rinus Michels, the legendary Dutch coach credited with developing "total football", died at age 77.
He led the Netherlands to a World Cup final in 1974 and an European Championship title in 1988.
His teams were known for their innovative playing style, which emphasized team coherence and individual creativity.
Michels coached Ajax to four national titles, Barcelona, FC Cologne, and Bayer Leverkusen, and was named coach of the century by FIFA.
He leaves a lasting impact on Dutch football as a pioneer who shaped the sport globally.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Legendary Dutch coach Rinus Michels passed away at the age of 77 due to heart surgery in the Netherlands on September 15th.

He played a pivotal role in shaping Holland's football legacy, guiding his team to numerous national and international victories including winning three consecutive titles with Ajax and being crowned World Cup champions against Germany in 1974.
Michels was known for his tactical approach of fostering cooperation between teammates and individual players by encouraging them to play creative football on the playing field.
He was also renowned for building a Dutch team around Johan Cruyff, a pioneering player who helped revolutionize Dutch football with his innovative techniques during his career at Ajax.
During his time as coach of Ajax, Michels played a crucial role in training and developing young players like Johan Neeskens, Johan Cruyff, and others.
He also worked under the leadership of Johan Cruyff, helping to shape Holland's style of play for future generations.
Michels had recently undergone heart surgery due to his condition, which he was one of the best coaches in history.
His passing marks a significant loss not only to his teammates but also to the sport of football in general.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Legendary Dutch coach Rinus Michels, known as the "General," has died at 77 years old after undergoing heart surgery.
Michels led the Dutch national team to European Championship titles in 1988 and 2014 World Cup qualification matches.

His innovative "total football" strategy emphasized individual creativity while fostering team cohesion across the pitch, building around Johan Cruyff and Johan Neeskens at Ajax and later on with FC Barcelona, Lyon, and Hamburg.
qwen2.5:3b: Legendary Dutch coach Rinus Michels, known as "the General," died at 77 after developing "total football."
He led the Dutch to World Cup final in 1974 and European Championship title in 1988.
Michels coached Ajax (four national titles) and introduced total football concept featuring team coherence and individual creativity.
His teams included stars like Johan Cruyff, with whom he won a FIFA coach of the century award.
He also coached Barcelona, FC Cologne, and Bayer Leverkusen.
opencoder:1.5b: The legend of Michels, the Dutch coach leading to the 1974 World Cup defeat by Germany, is now out of print.
Michels died aged 77, and the coach named in the text has since lost five titles at five different clubs.
smollm:1.7b: Michels, the legendary Dutch coach and general manager of the Dutch national team, died on January 24 at the age of 77.
He is remembered for his innovative approach to coaching, which emphasized teamwork and individual creativity.
Michels was known for his no-nonsense style and was often referred to as "the General" by his peers.
Michels played for Ajax from 1965 to 1971 and was a key figure in the Dutch team's success at the 1974 World Cup, where they reached the final only to lose 2-1 to Germany.
However, he guided his side to the 1988 European Championship title with a 2-0 win over the Soviet Union in the final.
Michels was also known for his work at FC Cologne and Bayer Leverkusen, where he won five caps for the Netherlands as a bruising centre forward.
Michels' legacy extends beyond his coaching career.
He is widely regarded as one of the greatest coaches in history, and his innovative approach to football has inspired generations of players and coaches around the world.

The Dutch national team's success during Michels' tenure was also marked by several memorable moments, including a 2-0 win over the Soviet Union at the World Cup final and a 1975 World Cup title with a 3-0 win over the United States.
Michels' passing leaves a void in Dutch football, but his legacy will continue to inspire future generations of players and coaches.
His commitment to teamwork, creativity, and individual imagination has made him one of the most beloved figures in Dutch sports history.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Michels, the legendary Dutch coach and football legend, passed away at 77 in the Netherlands.

Known as "the General," he led the Dutch national team through significant milestones: winning a World Cup final against Germany in 1974, securing a European Championship title over the Soviet Union in 1988, coaching four national titles from 1965 to 1971, and earning five caps for the Netherlands as a center forward.
His innovative approach to total football, emphasizing team unity and creativity, solidified his legacy as one of history's greatest coaches.

Known for his "total football" strategy, he coached Ajax to four domestic championships and introduced the concept of "creative attacking football."
He also had a spell at Barcelona, where he won the Spanish title in 1974.
Michel is remembered as one of the greatest coaches in Dutch history, and he was named coach of the century by world football's governing body Fifa in 1999.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Rinus Michels, known as "the General," the legendary Dutch coach credited with inventing "total football," died at 77.

His 1970s Dutch team, featuring Johan Cruyff and Johan Neeskens, embodied total football, a strategy that required all players to be versatile and skilled enough to play any position.
Michels had undergone heart surgery recently but remained highly regarded by the Dutch football federation (KNVB) as one of their greatest coaches.
